categories.name: factoid
categories.description: Question seeking a specific, concise piece of information or a short fact about a particular subject, such as a name, date, or number (e.g., ‘When was Napoleon born?’).

categories.name: open-ended
categories.description: Question inviting detailed or exploratory responses, encouraging discussion or elaboration. (e.g., ‘what caused the French revolution?’).

categories.name: non-factoid-experience
categories.description: A question to get advice or recommendations on a particular topic.

categories.name: direct
categories.description: Question that does not contain any premise or any information about the user (e.g., ‘what is the fee for speeding in Italy?’).

categories.name: with-premise
categories.description: Question starting with a very short premise, where the user reveals their needs or some information about himself (e.g., ‘I have an H1-B visa for the United States. Is there a limit to how many times I can exit and enter the country in a year?’).

categories.name: concise-and-natural
categories.description: Phrased in the way people typically speak, reflecting everyday language use, without formal or artificial structure. It is a concise direct question consisting of less than 10 words (e.g., ‘what’s the weather like in Paris now?’).

categories.name: verbose-and-natural
categories.description: Phrased in the way people typically speak, reflecting everyday language use, without formal or artificial structure. It is a relatively long question consisting of more than 9 words (e.g., ‘I thought of visiting Paris this year, not sure when is the best time. How is it like in the summer?’).

categories.name: short-search-query
categories.description: Phrased as a typed web query for search engines (only keywords, without punctuation and without a natural-sounding structure). It consists of less than 7 words (e.g., ‘Paris weather August’).

categories.name: long-search-query
categories.description: Phrased as a typed web query for search engines (only keywords, without punctuation and without a natural-sounding structure). It consists of more than 6 words (e.g., ‘Paris, France temperature humidity climate summer vs fall’).

categories.name: telegraphic
categories.description: Questions of a very brief, keyword-like nature, often omitting function words (e.g., 'Julia Alvarez parents?').

categories.name: similar-to-document
categories.description: Phrased using the same terminology and phrases appearing in the document (e.g., for the document ‘The Amazon River has an average discharge of about 215,000–230,000 m3/s’, ‘what is the average discharge of the Amazon river’).

categories.name: distant-from-document
categories.description: Phrased using terms completely different from the ones appearing in the document (e.g., for a document ‘The Amazon River has an average discharge of about 215,000–230,000 m3/s’, ‘How much water run through the Amazon?’).

categories.name: simple
categories.description: Question requiring retrieval of a single fact or simple temporal information from the context [2].

categories.name: medium
categories.description: Question involving multiple context facts and potentially requiring temporal semantic operations [2].

categories.name: complex
categories.description: Question requiring retrieval of multiple facts and potentially complex temporal reasoning, arithmetic, or ranking operations [2].

categories.name: comparison
categories.description: Question that includes comparison conditions (e.g., 'What country has the highest population...?') [3].

categories.name: temporal
categories.description: Question that includes temporal conditions (e.g., '...in the year 2008?') [3].

categories.name: no_entities
categories.description: Question containing no named entities (e.g., 'What public company has the most employees in the world?') [3].

categories.name: multiple_entities
categories.description: Question containing two or more named entities, reflecting compositional nature [3].

categories.name: answerable
categories.description: Question for which an answer can be derived from the provided context/knowledge base.

categories.name: unanswerable
categories.description: Question for which an answer cannot be derived from the provided context/knowledge base (e.g., 'Who was the first human being on Mars?') [3].

categories.name: entity
categories.description: Question whose expected answer is a named entity (e.g., person, organization, location) [3].

categories.name: literal
categories.description: Question whose expected answer is a literal value like a number or date [3].

categories.name: fine-grained
categories.description: Question seeking a specific, fine-grained type of answer (e.g., 'sports manager', 'species').

categories.name: general
categories.description: Question on a general knowledge topic.

categories.name: specific_domain
categories.description: Question related to a specific domain like geography, movies, sports, science, etc. [3].

categories.name: definition
categories.description: Seeking the meaning or explanation of a term, concept, or entity (e.g., 'What is quantum entanglement?').

categories.name: explanation
categories.description: Seeking reasons, causes, or mechanisms behind a phenomenon or event (e.g., 'Why is the sky blue?', 'How does photosynthesis work?').

categories.name: procedural
categories.description: Seeking step-by-step instructions or methods to accomplish a task (e.g., 'How do I bake sourdough bread?').

categories.name: confirmation
categories.description: Seeking to verify a piece of information or a belief (e.g., 'Is it true that bats are blind?').

categories.name: hypothetical
categories.description: Posing a speculative scenario and asking about potential outcomes or consequences (e.g., 'What would happen if the Earth stopped spinning?').

categories.name: opinion_seeking
categories.description: Requesting subjective viewpoints, recommendations, or judgments, although the RAG system should aim for objective summaries if possible (e.g., 'What is the best programming language for beginners?').

categories.name: list_seeking
categories.description: Explicitly asking for a list of items, examples, or features (e.g., 'List the planets in the solar system.', 'What are the symptoms of the flu?').

categories.name: single_focus
categories.description: Asking about one specific entity, event, or concept (e.g., 'What is the capital of France?').

categories.name: multi_part
categories.description: Containing multiple related sub-questions within a single query (e.g., 'What is the capital of France and what is its population?').

categories.name: comparative_explicit
categories.description: Explicitly comparing two or more entities or concepts using comparative language (e.g., 'Which is larger, Jupiter or Saturn?').

categories.name: conditional
categories.description: Posing a question based on a specific condition being met (e.g., 'If I invest $1000, what might be the return in 5 years?').

categories.name: implicit_request
categories.description: Phrased as a statement that implies a need for information rather than an explicit question (e.g., 'Tell me about the history of the internet.').

categories.name: unambiguous
categories.description: Having a clear and single interpretation (e.g., 'What is the boiling point of water at sea level?').

categories.name: lexical_ambiguity
categories.description: Containing words with multiple meanings that could change the question's intent (e.g., 'What is a bank?' - financial institution or river side?).

categories.name: syntactic_ambiguity
categories.description: Having a grammatical structure that allows for multiple interpretations (e.g., 'I saw the man with the telescope.' - Who has the telescope?).

categories.name: scope_ambiguity
categories.description: Ambiguity regarding the scope of modifiers or quantifiers (e.g., 'List companies that don't use fossil fuels.' - Completely? Primarily?).

categories.name: neutral_fact_based
categories.description: Based on generally accepted facts or neutral framing (e.g., 'What are the main components of a car engine?').

categories.name: contains_unverified_premise
categories.description: Based on an assumption that might be questionable or requires verification (e.g., 'Since the moon landing was faked, who directed the footage?'). Note: Distinct from 'unanswerable' as it might be answerable *if* the premise was true, or requires addressing the premise.

categories.name: requires_specific_context
categories.description: Assumes knowledge of a very specific cultural, technical, or personal context not universally shared (e.g., 'What was the outcome of the Q2 project review meeting?').

categories.name: loaded_question
categories.description: Contains a controversial or unjustified assumption, often aiming to trap the answerer (e.g., 'Have you stopped using unethical data sources?').

categories.name: historical
categories.description: Pertaining to past events, figures, or periods (e.g., 'Who was the first president of the United States?').

categories.name: contemporary_current
categories.description: Pertaining to recent or ongoing events, current state of affairs (e.g., 'What is the current unemployment rate in Germany?', 'Who won the latest F1 race?'). Requires up-to-date information.

categories.name: future_speculative
categories.description: Asking about predictions, forecasts, or future possibilities (e.g., 'What will the weather be like tomorrow?', 'Will AI achieve general intelligence by 2030?').

categories.name: atemporal
categories.description: Asking about concepts or facts that are generally considered timeless or not tied to a specific period (e.g., 'What is the chemical formula for water?', 'What are the rules of chess?').

categories.name: single_fact_retrieval
categories.description: Requires retrieving a single, discrete piece of information from the context.

categories.name: multi_fact_synthesis
categories.description: Requires retrieving multiple pieces of information and synthesizing them into a coherent answer (e.g., summarizing differences, explaining a process based on scattered details).

categories.name: list_generation
categories.description: Requires extracting and presenting multiple items as a list. (e.g., 'List the planets in the solar system.').

categories.name: summary_generation
categories.description: Requires condensing information from one or more sources into a shorter summary. (e.g., summarizing a long article or report).

categories.name: binary_decision
categories.description: Requires a yes/no or true/false answer. (e.g., 'Is the sky blue?').

categories.name: binary_decision_justification
categories.description: Requires a yes/no or true/false answer, often followed by justification or explanation based on retrieved evidence. (e.g., 'Is the sky blue? Why or why not?').

categories.name: causal_inference
categories.description: Requires inferring cause-and-effect relationships from the provided context. (e.g., 'What caused the Great Depression?').

categories.name: neutral_objective
categories.description: Phrased neutrally, seeking objective information without indicating a preferred viewpoint (e.g., 'What are the arguments for and against nuclear power?').

categories.name: implies_positive_bias
categories.description: Phrased in a way that suggests a positive view of the subject (e.g., 'Explain the benefits of renewable energy.').

categories.name: implies_negative_bias
categories.description: Phrased in a way that suggests a negative view of the subject (e.g., 'What are the dangers of artificial intelligence?').

categories.name: requests_specific_perspective
categories.description: Explicitly asks for information reflecting a particular viewpoint or stakeholder perspective (e.g., 'From an environmental perspective, what are the impacts of tourism?').

categories.name: formal_academic
categories.description: Uses formal language, complex sentence structures, and precise terminology, typical of academic or professional contexts (e.g., 'Elucidate the principal mechanisms underlying cellular respiration.').

categories.name: informal_colloquial
categories.description: Uses everyday language, slang, contractions, and simpler sentence structures (e.g., 'Hey, what's the deal with that K-pop band everyone's talking about?').

categories.name: technical_jargon
categories.description: Includes specialized terms or jargon specific to a field, potentially difficult for a general audience (e.g., 'What is the optimal hyperparameter configuration for fine-tuning BERT on SQuAD?').

categories.name: concrete
categories.description: Asking about specific, tangible entities, objects, people, places, or events (e.g., 'What material is the Eiffel Tower made of?', 'Who directed the movie Inception?').

categories.name: abstract
categories.description: Asking about concepts, ideas, theories, qualities, or relationships that are not directly tangible (e.g., 'What is justice?', 'Explain the concept of cognitive dissonance.', 'What defines happiness?').

categories.name: mixed_concrete_abstract
categories.description: Asking about the relationship between concrete examples and abstract concepts (e.g., 'How does the French Revolution exemplify the idea of liberty?', 'What abstract principles guide the design of sustainable architecture?').

categories.name: exact_value
categories.description: Requires a precise numerical value, date, name, or specific term (e.g., 'What is the exact value of pi to 5 decimal places?', 'On what date did World War II end?').

categories.name: approximate_range
categories.description: Satisfied by an estimated value, range, or general category (e.g., 'About how many people live in Tokyo?', 'What is the typical lifespan of a dog?').

categories.name: qualitative_descriptive
categories.description: Requires a descriptive, non-numerical answer explaining qualities, characteristics, or processes (e.g., 'Describe the climate of the Mediterranean region.', 'What are the main themes in Hamlet?').

categories.name: culturally_universal
categories.description: Likely understandable and answerable regardless of specific cultural background (e.g., 'What is photosynthesis?', 'How many continents are there?'). Assumes basic global knowledge.

categories.name: culturally_specific
categories.description: Relies on knowledge of specific cultural norms, traditions, idioms, history, or references (e.g., 'What is the significance of Dia de Muertos in Mexico?', 'Explain the rules of cricket.', 'What does 'spill the tea' mean?').

categories.name: regionally_specific
categories.description: Relies on knowledge specific to a particular geographic region, potentially crossing cultural lines within that region (e.g., 'What are the best hiking trails in the Alps?', 'Describe the traffic patterns in downtown Los Angeles.').

categories.name: self_contained
categories.description: Fully understandable without reference to prior conversation turns (e.g., 'What is the capital of Australia?').

categories.name: anaphoric_reference
categories.description: Contains pronouns or references (like 'it', 'that', 'the previous one') that depend on entities mentioned in a preceding (hypothetical) turn (e.g., following 'Paris is nice.', the question 'What is *its* population?' depends on the previous turn).

categories.name: elliptical
categories.description: Omits parts of the question that are implied by the preceding context (e.g., following 'Tell me about Python.', the next query 'And Java?' implicitly means 'Tell me about Java.').

categories.name: follow_up_clarification
categories.description: Seeks clarification or more detail on a previous answer or topic (e.g., 'Can you elaborate on the first point you mentioned?', 'What do you mean by 'significant impact'?').

categories.name: grammatically_correct_standard
categories.description: Well-formed question following standard grammar and spelling rules.

categories.name: contains_typos_spelling_errors
categories.description: Includes minor typographical or spelling mistakes that might require error tolerance (e.g., 'What is the temprature in Londn?').

categories.name: grammatically_incorrect_non_standard
categories.description: Contains grammatical errors or non-standard sentence structures, but intent is likely decipherable (e.g., 'How much people live New York City?').

categories.name: includes_irrelevant_text
categories.description: Contains extraneous words or phrases not essential to the core query (e.g., 'Okay so I was wondering, like, what is the main export of Brazil, you know?').

categories.name: fragment
categories.description: An incomplete question or phrase representing a query (e.g., 'causes of climate change'). Similar to search queries but might appear mid-conversation.

categories.name: neutral_benign
categories.description: Asks for standard factual or explanatory information without obvious ethical implications.

categories.name: potentially_sensitive
categories.description: Touches upon topics that can be sensitive due to personal beliefs, social issues, or privacy concerns (e.g., politics, religion, health conditions, financial advice).

categories.name: requests_potentially_harmful_content
categories.description: Asks for information or instructions that could be used for harmful, dangerous, illegal, or unethical activities (e.g., how to build weapons, promote hate speech, perform illegal acts).

categories.name: explores_bias_stereotypes
categories.description: Asks about or may elicit biased information or stereotypes, requiring careful handling (e.g., 'Why are certain groups perceived as...?').

categories.name: seeks_advice_critical_domains
categories.description: Asks for advice in high-stakes domains like medical, legal, or financial, where incorrect information could have severe consequences.

categories.name: simple_retrieval
categories.description: Answer is likely directly stated in a single passage of the source text.

categories.name: multi_hop_retrieval
categories.description: Requires connecting information from multiple passages or documents to formulate the answer.

categories.name: numerical_calculation
categories.description: Requires performing mathematical operations (addition, subtraction, averaging, etc.) on retrieved numerical data (e.g., 'What is the total population of California and Texas?').

categories.name: logical_deduction
categories.description: Requires applying logical rules (e.g., if A implies B, and A is true, then B is true) to retrieved facts.

categories.name: commonsense_reasoning
categories.description: Requires applying general world knowledge or understanding of typical situations not explicitly stated in the text (e.g., inferring intent or cause based on common scenarios).

categories.name: temporal_reasoning
categories.description: Requires understanding and reasoning about sequences of events, time durations, or points in time based on retrieved information.

categories.name: general_knowledge
categories.description: Pertains to widely known facts and common topics accessible to a broad audience (e.g., 'What causes rain?').

categories.name: specialized_academic
categories.description: Relates to a specific field of study requiring expert knowledge (e.g., 'Explain the mechanism of CRISPR-Cas9 gene editing.', 'What are the implications of Gödel's incompleteness theorems?').

categories.name: niche_hobbyist
categories.description: Focuses on topics related to specific hobbies, interests, or fandoms that may have detailed but non-academic knowledge bases (e.g., 'What is the best way to prune a bonsai ficus?', 'List all characters who wielded the Infinity Gauntlet in Marvel comics.').

categories.name: current_events_news
categories.description: Relates to very recent news, political developments, or ongoing events requiring up-to-the-minute information (e.g., 'What were the results of yesterday's election?', 'Summarize the latest developments in the international summit.').

categories.name: hyper_local_knowledge
categories.description: Pertains to information specific to a very small geographic area or community (e.g., 'When is the next town council meeting in Smallville?', 'What are the opening hours for the local bakery on Elm Street?').

categories.name: requests_visual_description
categories.description: Asks for a description of something visual, implicitly requesting translation from visual to text (e.g., 'Describe the Mona Lisa painting.', 'What does a tardigrade look like?').

categories.name: requests_spatial_information
categories.description: Asks for directions, layout, or relative positions best represented spatially (e.g., 'How do I get from the train station to the museum?', 'Describe the layout of the solar system.').

categories.name: requests_auditory_description
categories.description: Asks for a description of a sound or music (e.g., 'What does whale song sound like?', 'Describe the main melody of Beethoven's 5th Symphony.').

categories.name: requests_data_table_summary
categories.description: Asks for information naturally structured as a table, requiring summarization or extraction in text (e.g., 'Compare the specs of the latest smartphones.', 'What are the nutritional values per serving for oatmeal?').

categories.name: requests_code_snippet
categories.description: Asks for a piece of programming code to perform a function (e.g., 'Show me how to read a file in Python.', 'What's the CSS code to center a div?').

categories.name: learning_understanding
categories.description: User aims to gain knowledge or comprehend a concept (e.g., 'Explain black holes.').

categories.name: problem_solving_decision_making
categories.description: User seeks information to overcome a specific obstacle or make a choice (e.g., 'How do I fix a leaky faucet?', 'Which type of investment is safer, bonds or stocks?').

categories.name: information_gathering_research
categories.description: User is collecting facts or data points, often for a larger project or comparison (e.g., 'List all Nobel prize winners in physics since 2000.', 'Gather statistics on global internet usage.').

categories.name: entertainment_curiosity
categories.description: User is seeking interesting facts, trivia, or exploring topics out of curiosity (e.g., 'Tell me a fun fact about sloths.', 'What are some famous conspiracy theories?').

categories.name: verification_fact_checking
categories.description: User wants to confirm or debunk a specific claim (e.g., 'Is it true that you only use 10% of your brain?').

categories.name: neutral_informative_style
categories.description: Implies a standard, objective, encyclopedia-like answer format.

categories.name: requests_specific_tone
categories.description: Asks for the answer to be presented in a particular tone (e.g., 'Explain quantum physics in a simple and funny way.', 'Describe the situation formally.').

categories.name: requests_specific_format
categories.description: Asks for the answer to be structured in a specific format (e.g., 'Provide the answer as a bulleted list.', 'Write a short paragraph summarizing the key points.', 'Present the comparison in a pro/con format.').

categories.name: requests_creative_output
categories.description: Asks for a creative piece based on information (e.g., 'Write a short poem about the water cycle.', 'Draft an email explaining the delay based on these facts.'). This heavily involves the LLM's generative capabilities beyond pure RAG.

categories.name: requests_role_play_persona
categories.description: Asks the system to answer as if it were a specific character or expert (e.g., 'Explain gravity as if you were Isaac Newton.', 'Answer as a seasoned travel agent...').

categories.name: direct_imperative
categories.description: Phrased as a direct command (e.g., 'List the benefits.', 'Tell me about X.').

categories.name: polite_interrogative
categories.description: Standard polite question format (e.g., 'Could you please explain...?', 'What is...?').

categories.name: hedged_tentative
categories.description: Uses hedging words suggesting uncertainty or softening the request (e.g., 'I was wondering if maybe you could tell me about...?', 'Perhaps you know what...?').

categories.name: includes_social_phatics
categories.description: Contains conversational fillers or social niceties not core to the query (e.g., 'Hi there, hope you are well. Can you tell me...?', 'Thanks in advance for finding out...').

categories.name: potentially_ironic_sarcastic
categories.description: Phrasing might suggest an intended meaning opposite to the literal words, requiring careful interpretation (e.g., 'Oh great, another explanation of blockchain that makes perfect sense?'). Interpretation is highly challenging.

categories.name: no_explicit_source_request
categories.description: Standard question not explicitly asking for sources or evidence.

categories.name: requests_supporting_evidence
categories.description: Explicitly asks for evidence, data, or justification for the answer (e.g., 'What evidence supports the theory of plate tectonics?', 'Why do you say that? Provide data.').

categories.name: requests_specific_source_type
categories.description: Asks for information specifically from a certain kind of source (e.g., 'What do recent scientific studies say about coffee?', 'Find official government guidelines on...').

categories.name: requests_citations_references
categories.description: Explicitly asks for citations or links to the source documents used for the answer.

categories.name: requests_multiple_viewpoints
categories.description: Asks for a summary of different perspectives or sources on a topic, implicitly requiring evidence from varied origins (e.g., 'What are the different views on universal basic income?').

categories.name: broad_overview
categories.description: Requests a high-level summary or general introduction to a topic (e.g., 'Give me an overview of World War I.').

categories.name: specific_detail_focus
categories.description: Requests a very specific piece of information or detail within a larger topic (e.g., 'What was the specific date of the Battle of Somme?', 'Which clause in the contract addresses termination?').

categories.name: exhaustive_coverage_request
categories.description: Asks for all examples, instances, or components related to a topic (e.g., 'List *all* the countries in Africa.', 'What are *all* the known side effects of this medication?'). Often impractical or requires careful scoping.

categories.name: comparative_scope
categories.description: Defines the scope by comparing entities or aspects (e.g., 'Compare the economic growth of China vs. India over the last decade.').

categories.name: temporally_scoped
categories.description: Limits the requested information to a specific time period (e.g., 'What were the major scientific discoveries of the 19th century?').

categories.name: geographically_scoped
categories.description: Limits the requested information to a specific region or location (e.g., 'What are the main industries in the Ruhr valley?').
